title: Max Loss vs Max Gain (Risk Management 101)

screens.headline: Know your max loss BEFORE you click buy
screens.text: Professional rule: Never enter a trade without knowing your worst-case scenario. Beginners chase returns. Pros manage risk. Let's think like a pro.

screens.headline: Max Loss vs Max Gain
screens.text: MAX LOSS = the MOST you can lose if everything goes wrong. For option buyers = premium paid (always defined). MAX GAIN = the MOST you can profit if everything goes right. For calls = unlimited. For puts = strike √ó 100. Know both numbers before entering EVERY trade.

cards.definition: How much you can make vs how much you risk
cards.example: Risk $500 to make $2,000 = 4:1 ratio. Risk $1,000 to make $500 = 1:2 ratio (bad). Target at least 2:1 for most trades.

cards.definition: Your loss is CAPPED at a specific dollar amount
cards.example: Buying options = defined risk (max loss = premium). Shorting stock = UNLIMITED risk. Defined risk = better sleep at night.

cards.definition: Betting too much on one trade can blow up your account
cards.example: Account = $10,000. Trade = $5,000 risk (50%). Three losses = broke. Keep risk to 2-5% per trade. Survive to trade another day.

screens.headline: Think of it like poker
screens.text: You're at a poker table with $1,000. You can see everyone's hands before betting (this never happens in real poker, but imagine)...

reveal_sections.label: Bet $50, Win $200 (4:1 odds, 70% chance)
reveal_sections.content: Great bet! Small risk, big reward, likely to win. Even if you lose, you're only out $50. You can try again. This is a 2:1 ratio trade with high probability.

reveal_sections.label: Bet $500, Win $600 (1.2:1 odds, 50% chance)
reveal_sections.content: Bad bet! Huge risk, small reward, coin flip odds. One loss wipes out your ability to keep playing. Never risk half your stack for 20% returns.

reveal_sections.label: Bet $900, Win $1,000 (1.1:1 odds, 90% chance)
reveal_sections.content: Terrible bet! Yes, you'll probably win... but one loss DESTROYS you. Can't recover. This is the 'risk of ruin' - betting too much on any single hand.

reveal_sections.label: This is position sizing
reveal_sections.content: Your account = your poker stack. Each trade = a hand. Bet small (2-5% risk), live to play 20-50 more hands. Bet big (50%), one bad hand = game over.

screens.question: You buy 1 call for $7.50 premium. What's your max loss in dollars? (No $ sign)
screens.hint: Max loss for option buyers = Premium √ó 100
screens.explanation: $7.50 per share √ó 100 shares per contract = $750 max loss. Stock goes to zero? You lose $750. Stock goes to $1 million? You still can only lose $750. This is the power of defined risk.

screens.question: Your account is $5,000. How much should you risk on ONE options trade?
screens.explanation_correct: Solid risk management! 5% per trade means you can lose 20 trades in a row before blowing up. That's enough attempts to find winners. Risking 50% = three losses and you're done. Survival > aggression in options trading.
screens.explanation_wrong: Think about survival: 50% risk = 2 losses = broke. 20% risk = 5 losses = broke. 5% risk = 20 losses before broke. Which gives you more chances to learn and improve? Professionals risk 2-5% per trade. Stay in the game!

screens.question: AAPL call: Risk $500, Max gain $2,000. TSLA call: Risk $500, Max gain $1,000. Both 60% win probability. Which is better?
options: TSLA call (lower max gain = more realistic)
screens.explanation_correct: Exactly! Same risk ($500), same probability (60%), but AAPL has 2x the upside. In 100 trades: AAPL = win $1,200/trade average. TSLA = win $600/trade. Always prefer higher reward when risk and probability are equal.
screens.explanation_wrong: When comparing trades, look at risk/reward ratio. AAPL = 4:1 (risk $500, make $2,000). TSLA = 2:1 (risk $500, make $1,000). Same risk, same odds, but AAPL pays double. Always take the higher ratio when probabilities are equal.

screens.question: Your max gain on this trade is $300. What's the MINIMUM max loss you should risk for a 2:1 ratio?
screens.explanation_correct: Perfect! For 2:1 ratio: divide max gain by 2. $300 √∑ 2 = $150 max risk. This means: win twice, lose once = net profit. Lose twice, win once = still profit. This is sustainable trading math.
screens.explanation_wrong: For 2:1 reward/risk ratio: your potential gain should be 2√ó your risk. Max gain $300 = risk no more than $150. Why? If you win 50% of trades at 2:1, you're profitable. Win $300, lose $150 = net +$150 per two trades.

screens.question: You bought a call for $500. It's now worth $1,000 (100% gain). Risk management says you should...
options: Sell at least half - lock in profit
screens.explanation_correct: This is professional scaling out! Sell half ($1,000), lock in 100% gain on that portion. Your remaining $500 position now has zero cost basis - it's 'house money.' Can't lose now. Let it ride for more upside, stress-free.
screens.explanation_wrong: Rule: Take profits on the way up. At 100% gain, sell at least 25-50%. Why? 1) Locks in real gains, 2) Reduces position size/risk, 3) Remaining position is now 'free' - house money. Greed kills traders. Profits pay bills.

cards.back: 1) Max loss (always defined for buyers), 2) Max gain (if any), 3) Risk/reward ratio (target 2:1 minimum), 4) % of account at risk (keep under 5%), 5) Your exit plan (both profit AND loss).
Never risk more than 2-5% of your total account on one trade. $10k account = $200-500 max risk per trade. This lets you lose 20+ trades in a row before blowing up. Survival = success.
50-100% gain = sell at least half. 200%+ = sell 75%. Never hold to expiration hoping for more. Pigs get fat, hogs get slaughtered. Lock in wins, let runners run with house money.

screens.badge_description: You know how to protect your capital!
screens.celebration_message: Fantastic! You now think like a professional trader - risk first, rewards second. Next: exactly how much to risk per trade.
